Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: First Light and Reionization with Lyman Alpha Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will use ground-based telesopes, kitted out with special purpose filters, to hunt for the most distant galaxies in the
Universe. These galaxies were the first to form and are probably responsible for radically transforming the matter in the young
Universe from a neutral to an ionized state. That state-altering transition sent the young Universe down a path that led to the rich panoply of galaxies, stars, and planets in today's mature Universe. The data acquired for the research will exhibit rich
patterns in the strength of the signal as a function of its electromagnetic frequency. As part of a novel outreach effort, the team will sonify these data, that is, convert them to audible frequencies and imprint them with rich patterns in the loudness of the signal. This allows the human ear to "detect" the most distant galaxies known. MP3 files will be developed and released along with explanatory material.

The aim of the project is to investigate when and how the early Universe became reionized, a key unsolved problem in cosmology. A
staged observational approach will be taken. In the first stage, data from narrow-band surveys will be acquired to find candidate
Lyman-alpha-emitting galaxies at redshifts of 7.7 and 8.8. In the second stage, spectroscopic follow-up of the candidates will be done
to confirm their high redshifts and form a luminosity function of Lyman-alpha-emitting galaxies. That function will yield constraints on
the degree of ionization of the intergalactic medium (IGM) at those redshifts. The team pioneered this luminosity-function approach, using
it to show for the first time that the IGM is largely ionized at a redshift of 6.5. The team's new work will place the first constrains
on the degree of ionization of the IGM at even more extreme redshifts. The spectroscopy will also be used to study other IGM
properties. The spectroscopic data acquired for the research will exhibit rich patterns in the strength of the signal as a function of its electromagnetic frequency. As part of a novel outreach effort, the team will sonify these data, that is, convert them to audible frequencies and imprint them with rich patterns in the loudness of the signal. This allows the human ear to emulate a spectrograph. MP3 files will be developed and released along with explanatory material.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project, different components were developed and mostly completed, all studying properties of line-emitting start forming galaxies at different redshifts (i.e. cosmic times). The aim of this study was to search for high redshift galaxies in the DAWN survey. A complementary program was started and completed using narrow-band imaging data from the High-Z Emission Line Survey (HiZELS) fields. This was the subject of a graduate student thesis (Dr Ali Khostovan). The student is now graduated and has received a NASA post-doctoral fellowship to work at Goddard Space Flight Center, Maryland. He is working with the collaborator on this NSF program (Drs. James Rhoads and Sangeeta Malhotra).

 Using DAWN data, a sample of star-forming galaxies at z > 7 were identified. Observing time was applied on the Keck Telescopes and optical and near-infrared spectroscopy of these sources were performed. These spectra were used to confirm the redshifts of these galaxies. About 3 nights of the Keck Telescope were spent on this project. The near-infrared spectrum shows signs of lyman alpha line in the spectrum of one of these galaxies (as shown in the attached figure). This identifies a redshift of 7.45 for the candidate galaxy. The spectrum is reduced again with different techniques to put limits on the line detection ( > 3sigma). A paper is being written on these observations and results.

The overall paper on the DAWN survey has been published. Following that, sources identified as high redshift candidates were followed spectroscopically (as explained in the above paragraph and enclosed figure), using Keck Telescopes. Study of the clustering properties of [OIII] and [OII] star forming galaxies was performed over the last 12.5 billion years. Clustering length of galaxies was estimated for z=0.8-3.2

(Hbeta and [OIII] emitters) and z=1.5-4.2 ([OII] emitters)- (Khostovan et al 2018 MNRAS 478, 2999). The nature of line emitting galaxies at z~5 was studied using HiZELS sample. Using 7,000 narrow-band selected galaxies, the stellar mass functions for the star-forming galaxies was constructed and their evolution with redshift studied, as well as the evolution of the Equivalent Widths (Khostovan et al 2016 MNRAS 463, 2363).  Also, a study of the star formation history and luminosity function of line emitting galaxies was performed to z~5 (Khostovan et al 2015 MNRAS 452, 3948).

The NSF program provided the opportunity allowing a study of the nature, star formation activity and clustering of star-forming galaxies as a function of redshift. It also identified candidates for high redshift galaxies that were followed up by optical and infrared spectroscopy.
